justification: In the Analyses section the authors write, “we computed sensitivity (d') and response criterion (c)… a larger value indicates a bias towards saying 'distorted' more frequently,” explicitly identifying the response criterion as the quantitative index of response bias.
The paper states, “For each block, we computed sensitivity (d') … based on the signal detection theory formulas,” indicating that d' is the metric used to measure perceptual sensitivity.

The Discussion explains that the researchers “track the sensory biases via a completely separate task,” and Experiment 3 “asked participants… to rate the subjective strength of face distortion they perceived,” linking sensory bias to these distortion ratings.

Results note that the decisional bias “could also be observed in reaction time… data,” and the authors examined “whether such decisional adjustment would be reflected in a change in RT… This was indeed the case,” showing RT served as an indicator of decisional bias.

The manuscript states that the evolving decisional bias “could also be observed in reaction time and confidence data,” and reports significant changes in confidence over blocks, supporting the use of confidence ratings to measure decisional bias.
